Dumesic a * a Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, USA Chemistry Department, Nanjing University, Nanjing, China Received 28 January 1994, accepted 3 June 1994 Abstract Kinetic studies were performed over silica-alumna and acidic zeolites to deterrnme the effects of temperature (from 600 to 700 K) and reactant pressures ( < 80 Torr) on the rates of methylamine synthesis from methanol and ammonia Related kinetic studies were conducted of methylamine dtsproporttonation reactions, methanol dehydration, and reactions of methanol and dimethyl ether with methylarnmes The results suggest that the reactive species for methylamme synthesis are adsorbed nitrogenous bases, while methoxy groups are reactive species for dimethyl ether production Disproportionation reactions may be important pathways for the production of the higher-substituted amines during methylamme synthesis The combination of rrucrocalonmetnc measurements, reported elsewhere, and kinetic studies suggests that acid sites are required to these reactions for the strong adsorption of ammonia and methylamtnes, and weak adsorption sites are required to facilitate desorption of adsorbed amine species from the acid sites Keywords Acid catalysts, Alumina, Kinetics, Methylamme, Silica, Solid acid, Zeohtes 1. Introduction The synthesis of methylamines from methanol and ammonia over acid catalysts is an important industrial process This reaction may also be a useful probe of catalyst acidity For example, in contrast to reactions such as hydrocarbon cracking, the products of methylamine synthesis are limited to three substituted methylammes, water, and dimethyl ether Furthermore, the small number of reactants and products allows for detailed studies of adsorption processes [ 1 ] Methylamine * Corresponding author ' Current address 3M Corporation, St Paul, MN 55144, USA 0304-5102/94/$07 00 1994 Elsevier Science B V All rights reserved SSDI0304-5102(94)00118-F 338 D T Chen et al /Journal of Molecular Catalyses 93 (1994) 337-355 synthesis also proceeds without catalyst deactivation over a variety of solid acid catalysts Most of the literature on methylamme synthesis relates to the goal of achieving high selectivity towards the lower-substituted amines, dimethylamme (DMA) m particular Mochida, et al studied a variety of metal oxide and zeolite catalysts and found that Lewis acid sites alone are not active for the reaction [ 2] They suggested that the highest selectivity to DMA was achieved over acid sites of medium strength In contrast, Weigert found that Bronsted acid sites associated with H-mordemte were not selective for the lower substituted amines and that Na-mordenite was more selective, though less active [3] Shannon, et al [4] proposed that a combination of strong and weak sites is necessary for high activity and selectivity, with weaker sites allowing for weaker adsorption of the methylammes and more facile methanol adsorption. These researchers suggested that Lewis acid sites may be associated with low DMA selectivity, and they performed studies directed towards the formulation of shape-selective catalysts for production of DMA [5-10] Small-pore catalysts such as ZK-5 [ 6 ] , rho [ 5 ] , and enomte and ehabazite [ 8 ] were found to have low selectivity towards tnmethylamme ( < 20%) , while the rho and ZK-5 exhibited high DMA selectivity ( > 50%) Similar work was conducted by Herrmann [ 11 ] and Segawa and Tachibana [ 12] The latter workers formulated a dealummated H-mordenite catalyst with high DMA selectivity The primary focus of the aforementioned literature has been the development of highly selective catalysts, and the corresponding kinetic data were collected at high conversions The present study was undertaken to probe the surface chemistry by collecting kinetic data at low conversions, m the form of turnover frequencies, activation energies, and kinetic reaction orders In addition, we report catalytic activities for the following related reactions methylamme disproporhonation reactions, reactions of methanol and dimethyl ether with ammes, and methanol dehydration Finally, we suggest catalytic cycles that are consistent with adsorption, spectroscopic, and kinetic data For our work we have chosen to study acidic silicon-aluminum oxides, which have proven to be effective catalysts for methylamme synthesis and which are used commercially It is important to note that we have specifically avoided the study of shape-selective, small-pore zeolites to insure that our kinetic data are not influenced by transport limitations In this respect, we have limited our studies to silica-alumna and the relatively large-pore zeolites Y, mordemte, and ZSM-5 2. Experimental A flow-through apparatus operating at 1 atm pressure was used for reaction kinetics measurements The reactor was made from a Cajon VCR bulkhead union with an inner diameter of 0 7 cm Gaseous reactants were fed to the reactor through mass-flow controllers (Hastings HFC) Typical flowrates were 580 cm3/mm for D T Chen et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 93 (1994) 337-355 339 Table 1 Catalyst acidic properties Sample Acrd site density (tcmol/g) NaH-Y-33 360 NaH-Y-65 1000 NaH-Y-82 1450 H-mordenrte 710 H-ZSM5-13 670 H-ZSM5-35 360 H-ZSM5-225 74 a silica-alumina 90 Bronsted/200 total e Value estimated from Sr/Al ratio of zeolite He and 7 cm3/min for NH3. Methanol was fed to the system with a syringe pump (Harvard Apparatus Model 11), typically at 0 4 cm3/h For methylamme synthesis reaction studies, methanol inlet pressures were typically held between 1 5 and 3 Torr, while ammonia feed pressures were typically in the range of 4 to 6 Torr Feed pressures were vaned as necessary to measure reaction orders or to conduct kinetic studies of related reactions (i e , methanol dehydration, methylamine disproportionation reactions, and reactions of methanol and dimethyl ether with methylamines) For these latter studies, methylamines were fed to the system through a Nupro needle valve The entire system was made of stainless steel and heated to 423 K Analyses of the feed and reactor effluent streams were performed using a gas chromatograph (Hewlett-Packard 5890A) with a packed column of 0 05 M/8% KOH washed Carbowax on Carbopack B Samples (20-75 mg) were first treated under vacuum for 1 h at 300, 473, 573, and 723 K, followed by calcination under flowing oxygen (100 cm3/mm) at 723 K The catalysts used in these kinetic studies are listed in Table 1 Three catalysts were prepared from NaH-Y zeolite (Linde), with 33, 65, and 82% of the Na exchange canons replaced by protons, and these catalysts are designated as NaHY-33, NaH-Y-65, and NaH-Y-82, respectively H-mordenite was obtained from Conteka Corporation. Two H-ZSM-5 catalysts were obtained from T Degnan of Mobil Corporation (Paulsboro) with Si/Al ratios of 13 and 225, and these samples are designated as H-ZSM5-13 and H-ZSM5-225, respectively Another H-ZSM-5 catalyst, designated as H-ZSM5-35, had a Si/Al ratio of 35 and was provided by W Haag of Mobil Corporation (Princeton). The amorphous silica-alumina catalyst was obtained from Davison Corporation and had an aluminum loading of 13 wt% The silica catalyst was a fumed silica obtained from Cabot Corporation (grade EH5) The acidities of the catalysts were assessed by infrared spectroscopic and microcalonmetnc measurements of pyndine adsorption The details of these measurements for the NaH-Y zeolites [ 13 ] , H-mordenite [ 13,14 ] , and silica-alumina [ 15 ] 340 D T Chen et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 93 (1994) 337-355 Table 2 Average enthalpy changes of adsorption on H-ZSM5-35 and H-mordemte (all values are m kJ/mol) Base Proton H-ZSM5-35 H-mordemte affinity dHs~ 8 dH-k dHs~ g JHw_k NH3 857 7 -151 -69 - 158 -72 MMA 895 8 -204 -98 -219 -91 DMA 922 6 - 245 -142 - 207 -134 TMA 938 5 -155 - 71 -140 -66 CH30H 773 6 -91 -42 -87 -60 DME 8079 -79 -66 -99 -71 H20 723 8 -61 -75 have been described elsewhere We report in Table 1 the number of Bronsted acid sites and the total number of acid sites for those catalysts that also display Lewis acidity Further microcalonmetric measurements of the adsorption of ammonia, methylamines, methanol, dimethyl ether, and water on H-ZSM-5 and H-mordenite catalysts [ 1 ] have been previously reported We summarize the latter data in Table 2 3. Discussion 41 Factors affecting damethyl ether production The rate of DME formation is inversely proportional to ammonia partial pressure for all catalysts studied This behavior indicates that ammonia blocks surface species involved m DME formation Infrared spectroscopy reveals only methoxy (CH30) species on the surface under conditions of methanol dehydration [1], therefore, methoxy species are the probable surface intermediates involved m methanol dehydration to DME, and these species are blocked by adsorbed ammonia or amines The rate of DME formation from methanol m the absence of ammonia is first order m methanol for all catalysts at 603 K Because the acid sites m the H-ZSM5 catalysts are widely separated, reactions between methoxy species on different acid sites are not probable Thus, methanol dehydration involves reaction of a methoxy species with another form of methanol that is not associated specifically with an acid site, e g , physisorbed methanol Earlier calorimetric studies have suggested the presence of two sites, one strong and acidic, the other being a weaker adsorption site [ I ] The first-order dependence of the rate of methanol dehydration on the methanol pressures can be explained if the acid sites are saturated with methoxy species (i e , the surface concentration is independent of the methanol pressure) while the concentration of physisorbed methanol is linearly dependent on the methanol pressure In situ IR studies indicate that the surface coverage by methoxy species is high under reaction conditions for methanol dehydration The rate of methanol dehydration to form DME m the presence of ammonia is also first order m methanol Infrared spectroscopic studies show that the surface coverage by methoxy species is low under methylamme synthesis reaction conditions We speculate that the surface coverage by methoxy species under these conditions is primarily controlled by the pressure of ammonia or methylammes, and thus the fraction of sites populated by methoxy species is a weak function of methanol pressure The rate of methanol conversion to dimethyl ether is significantly slower m the presence of ammonia or other amines Accordingly, this reaction pathway is suppressed under methylamme synthesis reaction conditions This behavior is further evidence that methanol dehydration takes place through an intermediate (e g , a methoxy species) that is blocked by adsorbed ammonia and methylammes 4 2 Effect of reactant pressures on reaction kinetics Prior to describing the factors controlling the observed reaction kinetics, it is important to examine the possibility of mass-transport limitations The extent of mtraparticle limitations can be assessed by the dimensionless Damkohler number for diffusive transport, RrP/CSDe, where R is the rate of reaction per unit volume, D T Chen et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 93 (1994) 337-355 349 rp is the radius of the particle, CS is the reactant concentration at the surface of the particle, and De is the effective diffusivity [ 16] Mass-transport limitations are negligible when the value of the Damkohler number is less than unity Under methylammes synthesis conditions, the value of this dimensionless group is approximately 0 06, suggesting that the reaction kinetics observed m this study are controlled primarily by the surface chemistry Kinetic studies of methylamme synthesis show that the methylamme formation rate is first order with respect to ammonia pressure for reaction temperatures from 603 to 723 K This result indicates that the surface coverage by ammonia is low under methylamme synthesis conditions This behavior is consistent with the results of m situ IR studies that show the surface to be predominantly covered with methylammes under methylamme synthesis conditions The origin for this behavior is that methylammes adsorb more strongly than ammonia [ 1 ] (see Table 2) For example, the pressure of methylammes at the reactor outlet is typically on the order of 0 2 Torr, about 500 times lower than that of ammonia at the highest pressures studied However, the heat of adsorption of MMA is approximately 55 kJ/mol higher than that of ammonia, and the surface coverage of ammonia is expected to be 1 % of the surface coverage of MMA at 623 K A result of this study is the understanding that the dependence of the methylamme synthesis rate on methanol pressure is rather complex H-ZSM-5 and NaH-Y-65 catalysts show negative orders with respect to methanol, while H-mordemte and silica-alumna show zero and positive methanol orders This kinetic behavior is surprising because methanol adsorption is relatively weak compared to the adsorption of ammonia and methylammes [ 1 ] (see Table 2), and the surface coverage of adsorbed methanol on the acid sites is expected to be low compared to the strongly basic methylammes The observed kinetic behavior can be explained m the following manner When methanol reacts with adsorbed ammonia to form methylammes, a first-order dependence on methanol pressure would be expected if the acid sites are covered primarily by ammonia, this behavior is observed for several catalysts at low methanol pressures As the methanol pressure is increased and the rate of formation of methylammes increases, the reaction products displace ammonia from the active sites (because methylamines adsorb more strongly than ammonia) The rate of methylamme synthesis decreases and approaches zero order m methanol The origin for the negative reaction orders with respect to methanol is not clear at present We suggest that this behavior may be related to the inhibition by weakly adsorbed methanol of methylamme desorption from the acid sites, as discussed later in this paper 4 3 Formulation of catalytic cycles The results of microcalonmetnc adsorption studies provide important information about the energetic stabilities of different molecules on the surface [ 1 ] It can 350 D T Chen et al /Journal of Molecular Catalysts 93 (1994) 337-355 be seen m Table 2 that the heats of adsorption of the amines on acid sites increase m the order NH3 < MMA < DMA, m accord with the proton affinities of these molecules The heat of adsorption of TMA on acid sites is similar to that of NH3, despite the fact that TMA has the highest gas-phase proton affinity; this behavior may be due to stenc factors Methanol adsorbs on acid sites with a heat of adsorption lower than that of any of the amines Thus, as noted above, ammonia and methylamme coverages should be much higher than that of methanol The microcalonmetnc studies also show that all catalysts possess sites on which the reactants and products of methylamme synthesis weakly adsorb with strengths ranging from about 50-140 kJ/mol These sites may be associated with hydrogen bonding or van der Waals interactions within the catalyst micropores A critical aspect m the formulation of catalytic cycles for methylamme synthesis reactions involves the possible role of surface methoxy species As noted above, we suggest that methoxy species are reactive intermediates m the dehydration of methanol to DME It is less clear whether these species are involved m the synthesis of methylammes from methanol and ammonia We now present a general sequence of steps that describes the essential aspects of methylamme synthesis and related catalytic processes The first steps m the sequence are adsorption and desorption of all reactants and products onto the weak, non-acidic sites of the catalyst, represented by # These steps are followed by migration of weakly adsorbed species to acid sites, represented as Bronsted acid sites, H', where ` represents the zeohric lattice oxygen The dehydration of methanol to DME can be represented by the following two reaction steps involving methoxy species (CH3 ). CH3 OH# + H " -- CH3 + H2 0# (1) CH3 OH# + CH; - H ` + DME# ( 2 ) The catalytic cycle for methanol dehydration thus consists of Steps 1 and 2. Conclusions Microcalonmetric and infrared spectroscopic studies, reported elsewhere, have been used in conjunction with the present kinetic studies to probe the catalytic cycles involved in methylamine synthesis and related reactions over acid catalysts The results of these studies have suggested the importance of both strong and weak adsorption sites in methylamine synthesis and related reactions The reaction orders with respect to ammonia pressure suggest that one of the reactive species is strongly adsorbed, 1 e , adsorbed nitrogenous bases for the production of methylamines, or methoxy groups for the production of dimethyl ether The reaction orders with respect to methanol pressure demonstrate more complicated behavior, suggesting that other reactive species may be weakly adsorbed Amme species can react with both methanol and dimethyl ether, although reactions with methanol are more favorable Disproportionation reactions are fast, suggesting that these may be important pathways for the production of the higher-substituted amines during methylamine synthesis The combination of microcalonmetnc measurements and kinetic studies suggests that acid sites are required in these reactions for the strong adsorption of ammonia and methylammes, and weak adsorption sites are required to facilitate desorption of adsorbed amine species from the acid sites Acknowledgements Kinetic studies were performed over silica-alumina and acidic zeolites to determine the effects of temperature (from 600 to 700 K) and reactant pressures ( < 80 Torr) on the rates of methylamine synthesis from methanol and ammonia. Related kinetic studies were conducted of methylamine disproportionation reactions, methanol dehydration, and reactions of methanol and dimethyl ether with methylamines. The results suggest that the reactive species for methylamine synthesis are adsorbed nitrogenous bases, while methoxy groups are reactive species for dimethyl ether production. Disproportionation reactions may be important pathways for the production of the higher-substituted amines during methylamine synthesis. The combination of microcalorimetric measurements, reported elsewhere, and kinetic studies suggests that acid sites are required in these reactions for the strong adsorption of ammonia and methylamines, and weak adsorption sites are required to facilitate desorption of adsorbed amine species from the acid sites.
